Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Nabiha Rizk, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-d Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (d) Work history.
One out of fifty-seven employee files reviewed had missing work history.
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-j Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee's
performance annually thereafter.
Three new employees did not have a performance evaluation completed timely.

2024 Interim Report, CAP approved 1/24/2025
2023 Renewal Report, CAP Approved 08/28/2023

care institutions; initial treatment plan

sign, and date an initial treatment plan for each

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 2 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
• Investigation report 2024SIC0001776 dated 11/26/2024 which confirmed
staff hit youth on the back of the head. A corrective action plan dated
12/15/2024 was approved that included staff involved was terminated
and implementation of retraining staff on the youth discipline and
behavior management policy.
• Investigation report 2025SIC0000555 dated 07/09/2025 which confirmed
staff completed an improper restraint and put his knee into the youth’s
back. A corrective action plan dated 08/06/2025 was approved that
included staff involved was terminated and implementation of retraining
all staff on the use of emergency restraints as to it relates to the
prohibition of the prone restraint.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 10 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:

During this reporting period the facility had 10 special investigations resulting in a
corrective action plan.
• SIR 2024SIC0001776 date 11/26/2024-CAP approved 12/15/2024. Rule
400.4158 (1) (a)(ii) Staff hit youth on the back of the head.
• SIR 2025SIC0000004 date 12/04/2024-CAP approved 01/24/2025. Rule
400.4158 (1)(a)(ii) Staff made threats to youth through statements and
sticking his tongue out. Rule 400.4109 Facility did not follow internal
suicide precaution policy. Rule 400.4162 (11) Facility is secluding youth
outside parameters of seclusion variance. Rule 4004163 (5) Facility did not
provide an incident report on a form prescribed by the department for each
incident involving the use of seclusion or restraint.
• SIR 2025SIC0000095 dated 1/17/25-CAP approved 1/29/25. Rule
400.4159 (5) Staff performed inappropriate restraint on youth. Rule
400.4163 (5) Staff restrained youth and failed to complete a restraint
report.
• SIR 2025SIC0000040 date 02/07/2025- CAP approved 03/18/2025. Rule
400.4159 (2) (g) Staff did not properly intervene when a youth was
restrained by another youth.
• SIR 2024SIC0001619 date 02/10/2025-CAP Approved 03/11/2025. Rule
400.4162 (11) Facility was found utilizing seclusion in a non-approved
manner by keeping youths in their bedrooms past normal wake up time
due to staffing issues.
• SIR 2024SIC0001637 date 02/20/2025-CAP approved 03/12/2025. Rule
400.4159 Staff did not complete the necessary documentation for an
incident that involved physical intervention and physical management.
• SIR 2025SIC0000220 date 02/24/2025-CAP approved 03/12/2025. Rule
400.4126 Staff failed to intervene or stop youths from popping up the door
locks.
• SIR 2025SIC0000326 date 04/04/2025-CAP approved 05/23/2025. Rule
400.4162(1)(a)(iv) Youth was secluded in his bedroom for 24 minutes due
to urinating towards staff.
• SIR 2025SIC0000363 date 04/28/2025-CAP approved 06/05/2025. Rule
400.4158 (1)(a)(ii) Staff pushed youth several times and pulled their shirt.
• SIR 2025SIC0000555 date 07/09/2025-CAP approved 08/06/2025 Rule
400.4159 (2)(e) Staff completed an improper restraint and put his knee into
the youth’s back. Rule 400.4158 (1)(a)(ii) Staff used both of their hands to
push and hold youth’s head down on the mattress. Rule 400.4160(a) Staff
completed an unwarranted restraint on the youth.
The facility has implemented and complied with many of their CAP action steps
sufficiently as evidenced by CAP reviews conducted quarterly. The facility has
improved in their implementation of CAP’s. They are currently working on their
active CAPs.

Financial Overview
The financial audit and budget were reviewed, and no concerns were noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The facility is compliant with PREA.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was completed timely, comprehensive and
reviewed all areas of noncompliance from the previous licensing review and the
special investigations. This inspection report outlines 10 investigations that
resulted in rule violations, with several repeat violations for rule 400.4158. The
facility has focused on retraining staff on the use of MANDT verbal de-escalation,
utilizing proper restraint methods, staff supervision, and following facility policy and
procedures. There was an increase in restraints in this inspection period, and it is
due to new admissions and adequately reporting/documenting all movement
restrictions per the rule. The facility continues to provide staff with training,
coaching, supervision and monitoring, to ensure staff are utilizing verbal de-
escalation. All incidents requiring physical management are immediately reviewed
by camera and replayed in weekly team meetings to ensure staff utilize
appropriate de-escalation techniques. Facility has been observed making
significant efforts to improve compliance with their CAPs. Ongoing monitoring of
CAP compliance will continue to assist the facility and ensure compliance with
active CAPs.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff reported they feel supported by management and have the necessary
training to do their job. Staff participate in weekly meetings to review incident
reports and address any concerns regarding youths. Director reports that some
mandatory overtime continues when needed, but staff have the option to sign up
for overtime to avoid being mandated.
The youths reported the facility is providing them with all necessary hygiene items,
they get enough food and have clothing/bedding. The youths are currently
participating in summer school, group therapy, outdoor activities, gym, music
room, and yoga. Youths reported therapy is helpful to teach them how to manage
their feelings. Some of the youths are participating in student council and feel their
concerns are being heard and addressed.
Description of Agency Walk Through

The facility was neat, clean and well organized and no concerns were observed.
The staff offices, pods, classrooms, kitchen, dining rooms, lounge, and control
rooms were viewed. The medical office and medication storage and dispensing
was observed.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
